PROCTEXT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Hamer) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilisation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 229 citizens), Harradine (from 466 citizens), Puplick (from 294 citizens) and Richardson (from 185 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Historical and Environmental Assets
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:-

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, recently discovered 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River Tasmania, equal in importance to those in the Vesers Valley in France, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. The constitutional basis for protecting historical and environmental assets remains weak.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a Referendum to amend the Constitution so that:-

The Federal Government has the duty and a right superior to state and local governments to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore, those things we hold in trust for the future-
Being relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance;
To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, to manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and in any other matter which might be seen to be in the same spirit;
In particular to prevent beach mining, preserve the Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and consider its extension into the Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Missen (from 22 citizens) and Vallentine (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 59 citizens) and Sir John Carrick (from 27 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned have great concern for the future development and research of the IVF programme and express that we are against ``Senator Harradine's Bill'' Human Embryo Experimental Bill 1985.
The Bill threatens the provisions as a treatment for infertility because it defines as `prohibited experimentation':
1. Any manipulation of a relevant human embryo;
2. Any procedure undertaken on, or involving the use of, a relevant human embryo;

3. The creating of a relevant human embryo in anticipation that the development of the full human potential of the relevant human embryo will be interrupted or of using the embryo, or of having the embryo available for use, in any experimenting by virtue of sub-section (1) shall be deemed to be prohibited experimenting for the purposes of this Act.
4. Wilfully destroy a relevant human embryo.
5. Wilfully allow a relevant human embryo to die.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Hawke Government's failure to correct the anomalies arising from the application of the assets test on pensioners, with the failure of the Australian Democrats to support Senator Messner's bill to repeal the assets test, is causing unnecessary hardship for Australia's aged, particularly those living in rural areas.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Hawke Government will itself take action to repeal its iniquitous and anomalous test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated video-cassettes which would allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therfore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, expecially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as is duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud:
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that Woodchipping and Clearfelling will destroy the Otway Forests, water catchments and jobs in tourism. Your petitioners therefore pray that you will protect the Otway Forests for the future, and refuse any licence to export woodchips from the Otways.

PETITION.TITLE: Pre-School and Child Care Services: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned of we, the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth our concern at the drastic and untimely reduction of funding to early childhood services in our State.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the Government's decision on the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we urge that the Australian Government express its concern to Indonesia over consistent reports of widespread human rights violations in East Timor, as detailed by Amnesty International, and that the Indonesian Government be urged to take steps to prevent killings, torture and arbitrary arrest and imprisonment, as has been recently reported.

We would further humbly request that the Australian Government use its voice at the United Nations to lobby strongly for the reinsertion of East Timor to the Human Rights Commission Agenda; that the above human rights concerns be raised at the General Assembly when the Decolonization Committee makes its report; and that steps be taken to initiate UN conducted negotiations between Indonesia, Portugal and representatives of the East Timorese people, including Fretilin.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cook (from 58 citizens) and Kilgariff (from 60 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we support the following Bills introduced by Senator Chipp:
Australian Airspace (Nuclear Weapons Prohibition) Bill 1985
Australian Waters (Nuclear-Powered Ships Prohibition) Bill 1985
Australian Waters (Nuclear Weapons Prohibition) Bill 1985
Nuclear Weapons Prohibition Bill 1985,

the passage of which would prohibit the entry of aircraft carrying nuclear weapons into Australian airspace, the entry of nuclear powered and/or armed ships into Australian waters, and the development, testing, manufacturing, transportation or storage of nuclear weapons in Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that all Senators, regardless of political affiliations, support these Bills-not just for our sake but for our children. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Belconnen Mall, Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
We the undersigned express our concern over the sale of the Belconnen Mall due to the likely detrimental effect on the provision of community facilities presently existing in the Belconnen Mall.

1. In particular we seek guarantees that the present Child Care Centre and Community Facilities be retained by incorporating the same into the conditions of sale of the Belconnen Mall and that the services will receive the same real level of funding and support currently provided by the Canberra Commercial Development Authority.

2. That a financial commitment to the Building of Stage 4 of the Belconnen Mall listed under Section 14C in the Ordinance of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority be undertaken. Stage 4 to consist of Community Facilities such as Community Hall, large glassed enclosed community park, exhibition space, health and fitness club, ice rink, amusement centre and office accommodation.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this petition be considered.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Fund Contributions and Benefits: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 percent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that your petitioners:
1. Are deeply concerned at the impact the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act has had upon the economic and social development of the Northern Territory.

2. Believe that the Act has curtailed the development of the mining industry in the Northern Territory, thus depriving the Territory of the income which would have otherwise been generated by the development of its mineral resources.

3. Are concerned at the effect of provisions in the Act which have led to the virtual dissection of pastoral leases, through the successful claims made upon stock routes. This has undermined the economic viability of some properties and created racial disharmony in the Northern Territory.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that-

The Government will amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act to restore Aboriginal land holders to a position no more or less advantageous than their non-Aboriginal counterparts, particularly in relation to applications to explore for or develop minerals on their land, and to ensure that a date is set by which claims for land under the Act should be lodged.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: that we oppose the introduction of the Child Care Amendments Bill 1985, on the grounds that the proposed amendments to the Child Care Act 1972 will result in a serious lowering of standards in the quality of care available to Victorian children.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should: vote against the Child Care Amendments Bill 1985.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that we believe that there are unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental, technical and ethical problems associated with the mining of URANIUM and the Development of Nuclear power, in particular:
(a) to the proven contribution of the nuclear power industry to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and the increased risk of nuclear war; and
(b) the absence of procedures for the storage and disposal of radioactive wastes to ensure that any danger posed by such wastes to human life and the environment is eliminated.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that:
(1) No new Uranium mines be commenced;
(2) No new contracts for the sale of Uranium be approved;
(3) Uranium mines presently in production cease with the fulfilment of current contracts;
(4) No new Uranium is supplied to countries making or testing nuclear weapons.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) applauds New Zealand's inspiring and far-sighted stand in banning nuclear-powered and armed warships from its ports and supports that country's courageous refusal to be `bullied' into changing its policy;

(b) condemns the heavy-handed rhetoric of Mr Peacock in describing the New Zealand Government as `delinquent' and his seeking, through a return to the policies and rhetoric of the Cold War era, to diminish the widespread aspirations of people in this region for a truly nuclear-free and independent Pacific; and

(c) whilst appreciating the fact that the Australian Labor Government has refrained from intimidating the New Zealand Government into changing its policy, calls on the Australian Government to actively support New Zealand's position on the banning of nuclear warships and urges the Australian Labor Government to adopt a similar stand to that of its New Zealand counterpart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes that the Federal Labor Government's proposal to outlaw legitimate business expenses will cause great hardship to many small businesses, not only in the restaurant industry, but in many other small businesses that are unable to afford expensive advertising campaigns and, instead, rely on personal contact to promote their product;
(b) notes that this proposal presents the Australian Democrats with an opportunity to do something effective for small businesses; and
(c) calls on the Australian Democrats to join with the National and the Liberal parties and reject Labor's anti-small business taxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I withdraw Business of the Senate, Notices of Motion Nos 3 and 4, standing in my name for this day of sitting for the disallowance of the Meat (Amendment) Ordinance 1985 and the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) Ordinance 1985. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee scrutinised the Meat (Amendment) Ordinance 1985 it raised with the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) firstly whether inspectors with powers of entry should compulsorily produce evidence of their identity to the owners of premises they enter. The Minister has explained to the Committee that production merely on request was in keeping with the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority's endeavours to emphasise its inspectors' educative, rather than enforcement, role under the Ordinance. Secondly, the Committee suggested to the Minister that, where evidence of identity was produced on request, it should take the form of a photographic identity card rather than written evidence as is presently the case. It is administrative practice to issue photographic cards and the Minister has undertaken to formalise this practice with an amendment to the Ordinance. The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation and advice and pays tribute to him for his willingness to amend the Ordinance to ensure the protection of rights.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Committee scrutinised the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) Ordinance 1985 it raised with the Minister two concerns: Firstly, in a prescribed action against the Red Cross by a person who contracted AIDS from a blood transfusion, the Ordinance provided a statutory defence to the Red Cross if, in supplying the relevant blood, it had obtained the appropriate declaration from a blood donor and tested the blood using approved equipment and methods. The Committee considers that the definition of prescribed action in which this defence could be used was so wide that it could have meant the defence was available even where there had been some negligence in the processes and methods of testing and transfusing blood which resulted in a person contracting AIDS. The Minister has agreed to amend the Ordinance and redraft the definition of `prescribed action' to eliminate this possibility. Secondly, the Committee was concerned that, if adequate insurance or a compensation fund was available for the Red Cross, there would be no need to have a statutory defence in the first place.

The Minister has agreed to amend the Ordinance by inserting a sunset clause effective on 31 December 1986. The Committee thanks the Minister for his help in this matter, including his readiness to discuss personally the issues with the Committee during its hearing. The Committee pays tribute to the Minister for his interest in protecting rights in this difficult area. I was unable to give notice of my intention to withdraw these notices of motion because of discussions I was having with the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to one of the items on this list.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is very concerned that, included in this list of papers that has been presented, is item 4 which is a statement on Australia's foreign policy presented by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in the House of Representatives yesterday. The text of that statement is simply being tabled. I know that many ministerial statements have been creeping into the list of papers that is tabled which I think is a bad precedent. Ministerial statements should be made separately to give honourable senators the opportunity to debate them immediately they are made in a full way instead of their being tabled with other papers, reports and so on in relation to which honourable senators have a very restricted opportunity to speak. Honourable senators have only five minutes to speak to these reports as there is a limited time to debate them each day. At this stage I simply register our protest at that statement being included in this list of papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on the same issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join Senator Durack in his registering a complaint about this matter. This involves not only item 4 but also item 5 and other similar matters on the list of papers. Item 5 is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Objectives, Achievements and Priorities in Environment, Conservation and Heritage-report, and the State of the Environment in Australia in 1985-report-together with the text of a statement by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment relating to the reports made in the House of Representatives on 25 November.

Items 4 and 5 are extraordinarily important matters affecting Australia. The import of this is that, instead of honourable senators having 30 minutes in which to debate these very important matters, they will have their time reduced to five minutes each if they are lucky enough to even be called to speak. The chances are, looking at the list, that these matters will not even be brought on. I just want to register the Australian Democrats' protest along with that of the Liberal Party of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make the same point in relation to item No. 20, the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory on retail trading hours in the Territory. It being item No. 20, we are not likely to have an opportunity to discuss it today. There was originally a dissenting report as well and there have been a number of changes. It is an important issue and I would have thought that time could have been allocated to discuss it.

—by leave-I certainly accept the points made by Senator Durack and Senator Chipp. I think it is really drawing a long bow to suggest that we should have a separate debate on item No. 20, but I know that matter is very dear to the heart of Senator Reid. Anything that even touches on the Australian Capital Territory provokes that sort of response. The reason the business has been arranged in this way is the same as the reason it has been so arranged in the past-because of the difficulties being created by what is happening in the consideration of the Estimates in this place. One has a responsibility to endeavour to get the Budget and the appropriations through on time. However, I will take on board what Senator Durack and Senator Chipp have said about those two reports and see whether we cannot make arrangements for better debate as I concede that they are hardly minor matters. There has to be a bit of give and take, and the sort of stone walling that has been going on in consideration of the Estimates does not make us particularly inclined to co-operate with anyone who carries on in the way a certain couple of senators have been carrying on in this place.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

PROCTEXT.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Joint Select Committee on Video Material meeting during the sitting of the Senate on Wednesday, 27 November 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not been advised of this proposal. I am a member of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material and I also have a very strong view about committees meeting when the Parliament is sitting. I am concerned about this, but I understand the reason why Senator Walters is moving this motion. I think she shares my view about committees meeting whilst the Parliament is sitting. We have notified persons desiring to give evidence to attend tonight and we are in a bit of a cleft stick. I just wish to register my formal opposition to the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I apologise to Senator Harradine because this was pretty rushed. We had to seek permission to continue our meeting this evening following the Government's announcement that it wanted to sit tonight. I apologise for not informing Senator Harradine that we intended to sit. No pairs will be granted and the Committee will adjourn should there be any divisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement concerning the motion on the Australian Industry Development Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the unique nature of the motion relating to the AIDC that was recently put before the Senate and passed, I believe there is a need to have some information about it and find out the reason why this has happened. The motion is required by the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act 1970 and this is the first time that this particular section of the Act has been used. This matter is covered specifically in section 8A of the Act, which deals with enterprises or projects in the national interest. The Act goes on to say that this can only be implemented provided a report has been furnished to the Minister in writing in relation to the enterprise or project. That was the malaria vaccine investigation and production project. The Minister is then empowered to give such guarantees as will enable the Corporation to provide finance for or engage or participate in the enterprise or project. Sub-section (7) of the Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister shall not give a guarantee under sub-section (6) unless each House of the Parliament has passed a resolution approving the giving of the guarantee.

It comes before the Senate today for that purpose. It is a little bit more than that, because the whole matter of malaria is of great inter- national consequence. It is estimated that 2,000 million people in the world are subject to malaria and over 200 million suffer from it. It is not a new complaint; it has been recognised as having existed for something like 3,500 years. Incidentally, it was one of the things that I understand contributed significantly to the fall of the Roman Empire.

Australia has been well and truly in the forefront of research into malaria for many years. I think that most Australian service personnel, of the Second World War in particular, came into contact with it. It is important to bring together the four organisations that are covered by this guarantee. The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute, opened only recently at a cost of $35m with something like 250 scientists working there, will play a very big part in this. The Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission has been in the forefront of sera and vaccine production over many years and has achieved a very high reputation. Dr McCarthy of CSL is recognised as being one of the very great men in this field. The Queensland Institute of Medical Research and Biotechnology Aust. Pty Ltd. is a consortium of considerable experience, excellence and high repute. Already considerable numbers of people are working in this--

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, this is not a short statement and you did not give any warning to anyone that you were going to do this. What is going on?

—There are already about 50 people working on this project. I believe that that it is a very important project for Australia in what we are doing in our region and in our participation around the world. I do not think that it is as important that I sit down to satisfy Senator Grimes as it is that the Parliament and the people realise that Australia is participating in a matter of considerable importance. I hope that Australia will be able to play a leading part in dealing with the dreaded scourge of malaria.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) Government Business take precedence of General Business for the remainder of the present period of sittings.
(2) (a) the hours of meeting of the Senate on Wednesday, 27 November 1985, be 10 a.m. to 12.45 p.m., 2 p.m. to 6.30 p.m., 8 p.m. to 10.30 p.m.; and
(b) the Sessional Order relating to the adjournment of the Senate have effect at 10.30 p.m. on that day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise more in sorrow than in anger about this motion, particularly about the way in which this chamber is being run at the moment. I do not blame Ministers. I do not want to attach blame to anybody; I just want to make the statement that this chamber is now so complex and the interest of senators to speak on issues is so high that the sitting times are not sufficient. The complexity of the political parties is such that the present circumstances and the present organisation of this chamber never ever permit any session of the Senate to be conducted properly. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) is one of the busiest Ministers and has one of the most unenviable portfolios in the Cabinet, and I do not blame him. The Minister who is in charge of the chamber, the Manager of Government Business (Senator Grimes), is one of the most hard-working Ministers in the Cabinet. He has enormous responsibilities, and I do not blame him. However, he is the person allegedly in charge of the House. I do not know what the solution is-whether the job should be passed to a junior Minister. The same problem occurred in the House of Representatives over the years and the Whips there were given much greater authority to act and negotiate than is given to the Whips of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me illustrate the problem. The Australian Democrats warned the Government three months ago that at the end of the session we would have a blockage or log-jam of important legislation that would have every one of the 76 senators wondering what day or week we are going to get up. I cannot tell anybody now whether we will be sitting here on 6, 13 or 20 December or whether we will be sitting in Christmas week. Not one person in this chamber can give me an answer to that. Surely, fully grown human beings ought to admit that this is an intolerable situation. Three months ago I suggested that we reduce the number of matters of public importance we debate. I do not blame the Opposition for bringing on matters of public importance for debate. However, the suggestion the Democrats put forward was that on broadcast day, Wednesday, we should let the Opposition bring on two matters of public importance and that there be no other matters of public importance for the rest of the week. On broadcast day honourable senators feel a sudden urge to speak that does not necessarily come over them on other days of the week. That is perfectly natural. I do not blame honourable senators at all for that. But let us face reality. Nothing was done. The matter was allowed to drift.

On 12 November, the week before we got up we were presented with 47 Bills that had to be passed before the Senate rose. On 12 November we did some calculations. I wrote to the Leader of the Government in the Senate on a confidential basis and sent a copy of the letter to Senator Chaney. At that stage, we estimated conservatively that it would take 155 hours of debating time to get through the Bills the Government had said were essential, whereas if we sat until 13 December, only 65 hours of debating time would be available to the Senate to conduct Government Business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps debate by computer would be better.

—There is no room for debate at all. It would take 155 hours of debating time to get through the Bills-we were very conservative in working that out-but we have only 65 hours left. Clearly, if we are to get through even a modicum of the Bills the Government regards as essential we will have to sit until 20 December. I had one of the Clerks draw up an amendment to Senator Grimes's motion which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Leave out paragraph (1).
(2) After paragraph (2), add the following paragraph:
`(3) That the Senate meet each week day until 20 December 1985.'.

Even that amendment, if agreed to, would not clear the backlog. When we met on Tuesday of this week I was informed by the Government that this week the Senate had to pass Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86-I remind the Senate that we have one and a half groups to go yet-plus Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1985-86 plus Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1985-86, on which almost every honourable senator will feel compelled to give words of wisdom, plus the Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985 to which my colleague Senator Macklin has many significant amendments to move, as does the Liberal Party. It is very crucial legislation.

It does not stop there. We have to get the Child Care Amendment Bill 1985 through this week-one of the most controversial Bills brought in this session. We have to pass the Pipeline Authority Amendment Bill 1985, the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill 1985, the sales tax Bills and the Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 this week. That is enough legislation for three weeks. We have to pass those Bills and the appropriation Bills this week. We are now being asked to sit tonight. I have not mentioned the tax package. Is that to be introduced this week? Is the House of Representatives rising on Friday?

TALK.START.PARA: —Thursday, I think.

—I thank the honourable senator. What will happen if next week the Senate exercises its right to amend, say, the entertainment expenses part of the tax package? Will that mean that the House of Representatives will have to be called back again before Christmas? That is the sort of thing we find absolutely intolerable, and I just put on notice the Democrats' strenuous objections.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the following statement without being critical of any honourable senator. I will not name anyone. I am informed that some departments have already run out of money and have had to borrow against the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Large payments are due on 2 December. I remind honourable senators that we are running perilously close to that date and we have not yet passed the Appropriation Bills, which in lay language are known as Supply. We are holding up Supply. I understand that the Appropriation Bills-the Supply Bills-must be passed today because it takes three or four days to get royal assent to them and the warrants issued. I make no accusations now and I will not mention names so that I cannot be accused of scoring points, but last night in this chamber two honourable senators took up two hours of time speaking on the Committee stage of Appropriation Bill (No. 1).

TALK.START.PARA: —It was necessary. I was trying to obtain information.

—It may well be that it was justified. I am not saying that it was or was not. I am saying: What is the use of Estimates committees if honourable senators speak on the Appropriation Bills to a chamber in which only three or four other senators are present, with 15 to 20 highly paid public servants present in the gallery and another 15 to 20 highly paid public servants in the corridors outside waiting all night to be called? What is the use of the Estimates committees? Should not the systems of the Senate be changed so that we can get some sanity?

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that a very significant report will be tabled in the House of Representatives today on the Nugan-Hand activities. Because a matter of public importance is listed for discussion in the Senate today-I do not deny the right of the Opposition to bring on MPIs-on trade union domination or some damn thing, the Senate will not be able to debate the report. Two important committees have to meet tonight, although the Senate will be sitting. I just wonder about next week. Has any honourable senator heard that there is an election on in South Australia? Does any honourable senator here think that there will not be an MPI every day next week? The situation is unreal. I believe that there ought to be urgent consultation between the party leaders in this place to try to get some sanity into the sitting arrangements for next year and also with regard to how this year's sittings will be concluded. It has to be done by consensus. I am not alleging that the Opposition is filibustering at this stage with a view to holding up Supply. That would be outrageous, and I do not even suggest it. What I do say to the Opposition is that some departments have already run out of money and last night two Liberal senators took up the time of this chamber for two hours. That is a fact; that is on the record. It may well be absolutely justified. I am only putting that down on the record-not by way of criticism but as a statement of fact.

If anybody comes to the Democrats in the next two or three weeks or whatever and asks us to gag or guillotine legislation to get it through, the answer will be a flat no. We believe at this stage that that sort of legislation, all of which is crucial--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! It is about time.

—It is all very well for Senator Walters to say `Hear, hear'. She has to realise that the Government has a responsibility to get some legislation through before the end of the year because it is crucial for the processes of government. It will not get it through unless there is some give and take by all parties and all personalities in this chamber, without forcing legislation through. I have not been in politics for the time I have not to know that legislation can never be forced through the Parliament except through consensus. Senator Sir John Carrick said that many times when he was Leader of the Government, and I totally agree with him. What I am doing now is making a plea for some sort of sanity, some sort of give and take on the part of all parties and all persons represented in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition would thoroughly agree with many things that Senator Chipp has said. There is no doubt whatsoever that there has been continued mismanagement of the Senate by the Government, particularly during this session. I do not know why, and I certainly do not want to point the finger at anybody, any more than Senator Chipp wants to, but one reason could be that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Grimes) was overseas for some period during the session. Be that as it may, the fact of the matter is that the program for this session, both in this chamber and in the House of Representatives, is a real mess. The Government started off with a program for the Budget sitting beginning in August and running through with the two Houses more or less sitting in tandem for that period, but the Senate sat on its own for one week without the House of Representatives and the House of Representatives then sat on its own without the Senate last week. It is quite clear, with the House of Representatives absolutely determined to get up at the end of this week, that the Senate will be sitting for another week at least, probably two, and, if Senator Chipp's amendment is moved and passed, probably three weeks after the House of Representatives gets up. The Government is responsible for the incredible mess that has occurred in the running of this Parliament this session.

SPEECH.PARA: The House of Representatives last week guillotined a number of important Bills. I do not know whether Senator Chipp is aware of what happened last week but there was hardly any time allowed for debate on a major Bill to amend the Companies Act. There were 200 clauses in the Bill and honourable members had less than three-quarters of an hour to debate the Bill. Clearly the Government cannot expect such cavalier treatment by the Senate as it will want to spend a good deal of time debating a Bill of that magnitude. There are also a number of other Bills of that magnitude on the list of Bills which are to be dealt with.

The Government has, at a very late stage, made what the Opposition considers to be a genuine attempt to rationalise its legislative program. We now have a list of Bills which, once the Appropriation Bills are disposed of, will total in effect 40, with the possibility of there being only two or three weeks in which to deal with them. That should not have happened, and I agree with Senator Chipp about that. But there is at this late stage-at the eleventh hour-some realisation by the Government of the mess it has got both itself and the Senate into. We applaud that effort and we hope not only that it will be continued in the future but also that it will be done at a much earlier stage of any sitting. One of the most striking things about this list is that the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, which the Government has given great credence to, has been taken off it. That is no doubt a sensible move. Nevertheless, it indicates how little belief or concern the Government has about its so-called Bill of Rights, which I hope it will realise should be abandoned altogether. I instance that as an example of a genuine effort by the Government to cut down the debate that would otherwise have been required during this session before we rise for Christmas.

The immediate question that Senator Chipp raises concerns the Appropriation Bills. These most important Bills, both for the Government and for the country, were not introduced into the Senate until 5 November. They have been introduced in the House of Representatives on Budget night, on 20 August, and did not get into this chamber until 5 November. We have not had any lengthy debate on the Appropriation Bills. They used to be the centrepiece of debate in this chamber during the Budget session. The Appropriation Bills are the Budget Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighteen hours of debate on them so far.

—That is very little debate for such important measures. They are the centrepiece of the Government's financial program. These Bills are vital for the Government. They were not introduced into the Senate until 5 November. They demand far more debate than 18 hours. If anybody listening to this debate heard that we were giving only 18 hours of debate to legislation which is passing $50 billion or $60 billion to be spent by the Government I am sure he would think that it demands much more debate than that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has at no stage said to the Opposition, or I think to the Australian Democrats, but they can speak for themselves-it certainly has never said it publicly-that there is any urgent necessity for the Appropriation Bills to be passed yesterday or today. They are listed for passage this week along with several other Bills. This week extends until 4.15 on Friday afternoon. The Government's list of Bills that have been programmed for this week is relatively modest. Clearly the Opposition will co-operate in achieving what the Government wants passed this week. The fact is that the Appropriation Bills are still to be debated in this chamber this morning. There would be more sense in our spending less time talking about these sorts of things now and getting on with the Appropriation Bills.

Senator Chipp has raised a spectre of the Government running out of money. That is obviously typically designed to get some headlines and attention from the Press. The Government has never indicated that sense of urgency to the Opposition or to the Senate. I do not think we can take much notice of some rumour that Senator Chipp has heard. The fact of the matter is that the Opposition will co-operate with the Government in getting the passage of the legislation it needs this week. I do not think that the Government is very worried about that, even though Senator Chipp may be.

The Opposition agrees with the other points Senator Chipp has made, but we are certainly not going to curtail senators' rights and duty to speak on the appropriation Bills. There are a number of matters which do arise on these Bills which are not dealt with in Estimates committees. For one thing, the Estimates committees were sitting about two months ago. Questions were asked then which have not been answered even now by the Government, as we found last night. Other matters arise over a period of two months that need to be attended to. Senators have a right to comment on information that is obtained from Estimates committees. Senator Chipp does not seem really to understand what Senate Estimates committees do. They ask questions and get information, and senators have a duty to comment and debate the information that they obtain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Garbage! If that was what you were doing we would not mind.

—Senator Ray would not be interested in the subject at all. All he wants to do is comment on a few political issues that arise from time to time. He is not interested in the business of government. We are interested in the business of government. We are interested in the Budget appropriations and we intend to debate them as required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments on this matter, which has cropped up before. I think one has to take a little bit of time to debate this motion at this stage when things are in such a desperate mess. I will not go into the question of the Appropriation Bills. They have obviously been very slow in coming forward. We have to look at the question of whether there is some duplication in the questions asked in the Estimates committees and the questions asked when the Appropriation Bills are before the Committee of the Whole Senate, but this would not really be a problem if it were not for this great swag of Bills which have been carted into this House at this stage of the year.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not as though this is a new factor. Immediately the Parliament returned in August I raised a question with Senator Button. Unfortunately honourable senators will not find it in Hansard because Hansard, with its glorious computer, cut out the question and answer, but I will make sure that every honourable member gets a copy. There they will see that in the first week we resumed in August Senator Button assured me that it was a terrible mess in June when there was a great mass of Bills. As Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, I complained that that Committee was treated with contempt by the mass of Bills to be considered. This morning I staggered down with four volumes of Bills and we had a short meeting to discuss them. Again, the Government is showing contempt for the Parliament. This is not entirely a result of the Government's messing around; the Opposition also has to be responsible and cut down on some of the motions which are put forward. I thought we were doing that, but apparently we may not be.

But it is basically a Government problem. Senator Button assured the House that the Government had learned a lesson from what happened last June and that the same mess would not occur, with the same gathering of legislation at the end of a session, which is an insult to the Parliament. It is designed to push through legislation without people having the proper knowledge of or a chance to look at the legislation. It is not an accident. It happened with previous governments as well as with this Government. We had the unctuous words of Senator Button in the first week of this session, saying that this would not happen. But it is happening as badly as ever. It is time for back bench members of this Parliament from both sides to take a hand in this and ensure that the Parliament is not turned into a laughing stock in the community as a result of its rushing through legislation which has not been properly looked at. I believe that, if necessary, we must sit longer in order to do the work properly.

Obviously the Government has known for some considerable time that this problem would arise. Why has it allowed the Sir Humphreys and others in this community to hold back Bills that ought to have come forward weeks ago and should have been given close consideration by committees of the Parliament? I heard only the latter part of what Senator Chipp said but what I heard was basically correct-that this is an insult to the Parliament and the Parliament should not be treated in this way. The Parliament should not think that it has to agree to guillotines, to rushing legislation through, just because the Government is unable to handle the work in both Houses. I therefore raise my voice in protest too, and I believe many other senators have the same view, that as members of this Parliament we are insulted by the actions of a badly organised Government. We are insulted by being treated with contempt by the Government with its actions and its disregard for the proper processes of the Parliament in considering legislation. I hope that some notice will be taken of this. I do not expect an assurance from Senator Button, who is not here, but I will ensure that all members receive a copy of the question and answer to which I referred so that they can see the hypocrisy of the Government on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard all this before, probably over the last 10 years or so.
—Eleven.

—Eleven years. There is one major problem with this motion and I will make a suggestion to overcome it. The major problem emerges from paragraph 1 which indicates that Government Business should take precedence over General Business for the remainder of the present period of sittings. Similar motions have been put for a number of years. It is disconcerting for private members, particularly those who are not in government but probably also for those in government, as they are unable to bring to the Parliament matters which are very important to their constituents. Such matters will now be ignored for the rest of this session with Government Business taking precedence. Those matters include quite serious ones that I have on the General Business sheet. I point out that I have been given no time for these General Business matters to be considered during this session. Of course, Senator Mason's Bill regarding the Chamberlains will not be discussed again this session. That is a matter of great moment for a large number of people in Australia. I suggest that between now and the beginning of next year the Government should think about this problem. In the early part of a session we do not have much legislation to consider--
—We don't have any.

—That is right; we do not have any. So is it possible at least to extend the period for General Business at that time? I make that suggestion because last week or the week before-I am not sure when it was-I had only one day in which to move the motion of disapproval of the Remuneration Tribunal's determination relating to the issue of de facto spouses. People said to me: `But you are to introduce a Bill on that'. I replied: `But, look, the fact is that the Government will be forced to move a motion to supplant General Business, under which that Bill is included, for Government Business'. I knew that would happen. I ask the Government to think between now and February next year about allocating extra time in the earlier part of a session. If it has to give precedence to Government Business at the end of a session, it should allow more time for General Business at the beginning of a session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I will not take much time but there are some things I must say. The first is that I must echo the words of Senator Harradine. I have heard this same debate every year for the past 11 years that I have been in this place. I have heard repeated many times the words that have been said by Senator Chipp, Senator Missen and others. By and large, I happen to agree with them. It is wrong that we have this log-jam at the end of the session. It is wrong that governments of any persuasion gag debate and rush through legislation. I remind honourable senators that the record is 43 Bills in one hour. The present Opposition when in government did not do too badly when Senator Withers put through 27 Bills in one hour. In the House of Representatives the Liberal and Country Party governments year after year gagged great chunks of legislation and pushed them through at the end of the session. It has always happened and it will always happen unless the system that we are endeavouring as a government to introduce on to an unwilling bureaucracy succeeds.

SPEECH.PARA: We have proposed much more stringent time limits for the bringing forward of proposals to Cabinet and for the bringing forward of drafting instructions to parliamentary counsel who have a terrible time in this situation. We hope that we can change that and change it very quickly. I add that we have a particular problem in the Senate. We have an increased number of senators and senators want to speak more often on more bits of legislation than ever was the case when I first came to this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit more days then.

—I am coming to that. We have matters of public importance almost daily. When the Government made an effort to sit for an extra week, as we did in order to consider the taxation legislation and have some legislation passed, only one piece of legislation was passed. Matters of public importance were raised every day and there were endless debates on all sorts of subjects. As I was away for the first couple of days and was jet-lagged for the next couple of days, I went right beyond the call of duty and read the Hansards of that week during the following week. Unbelievable nonsense went on that week. What Senator Missen says is right. If we are to succeed, I agree with Senator Townley that it is very likely that we will have to sit more often as a result of the increased number of senators. If we are to have 14 to 15 speakers on the most minor bits of legislation, so that honourable senators can wear their arms out pumping the parish pump, we will have to sit more hours. If we are to have matters of public importance raised almost every day of the week, we will have to sit more hours. If we are to give reasonable consideration to committee reports and papers, we will have to sit more hours, whether people like it or not.

SPEECH.PARA: Over my years in this place I have noticed that the people who make the most fuss about this at the end of the year, about not wanting to cut short debate in the Senate and about wanting to sit more hours to have more time to consider things, are the first ones on the planes overseas when the Senate rises. They are the first ones to ask for a pair for the last few days of a session. It is hopeless and we have to stop that sort of hypocrisy too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let the Senate consider these things seriously. Abolish pairing at that time.

—Maybe we should abolish pairing but I so not think that will succeed in doing very much. I am making the point that the people who rise frequently to make the most impassioned speeches are those who are among the first down at the Transport Office to get cars and those who are first on the aeroplanes out of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Sir Humphreys about whom Senator Missen talks will obviously try to sabotage it, I believe that we are introducing a system by which we can overcome the sort of log-jams that we have overcome now. But clearly, we shall need co-operation in this place. The final place in which we shall need co-operation is, as Senator Chipp has said, on the Estimates committees and in the way in which we deal with appropriations.

As Manager of Opposition Business in this place, I did not think that there was much point, and I did not think that it was particularly useful, in the way in which a couple of my colleagues went on about appropriations at that time. But it was very difficult to do anything about it-as it is, obviously, difficult for Senator Chaney and Senator Durack to do anything about it. If people are going to get up on the appropriations and carry on in the way that they have been carrying on in this place, there is nothing much that anyone can do about it without depriving them of their freedom of operation as senators. But we have had 18 hours of debate on the appropriations. We have had endless hours in the Estimates committees. Whether one likes it or not, people rise in this place and ask questions that have been asked and have been answered in the Estimates committees. They ask the most obscure questions about policy, knowing that frequently there is no one present who can answer them in detail. But above all, they get up and treat this place like a municipal council and go on and on about things which could perfectly reasonably be covered by questions on notice, by ordinary letters to Ministers, by the adjournment debate, and by any of the other mechanisms that we have in this place.

An exercise that all honourable senators should go through is to read the Hansard reports of the appropriations debates and the Estimates debates. We are all at fault. In opposition I was at fault. In government I suppose I am at fault. But any reform of this type will take co- operation, on both sides; otherwise Senator Harradine will never get a private member's Bill near the Notice Paper, let alone after a couple of years, and we shall never have any reasonable debate on many of the important things brought before this chamber.

In this chamber, I always think it is interesting that if we are presented with a piece of obscure legislation involving the expenditure of a couple of thousand dollars, or no expenditure at all, on something which affects small regional areas, we are just as likely to have 15 half-hour speeches and endless speeches in the Committee stage. When the social security Bill comes through, year after year, dealing with the poorest people in the community, we have three or four speakers and, in my time, hardly anything in the Committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because you put it on in the last two or three days.

—Never! I am talking about social security Bills at any time of the year. On anyone's judgment, looking at the relative importance of legislation in this place, one finds that it is in inverse proportion to the hours that we spend in debate on it-with the exception of the appropriations, and the things on which we spend our time in the appropriations are frequently those which are nonsensical.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with all honourable senators that the way in which we go on at the end of sessions is mad; it is mad that we end up with this log-jam. But the fault lies on both sides. We shall need sensible co-operation, and part of that co-operation for which I ask is this motion, which would give Government Business precedence over General Business for the rest of the session-and would mean that we sit tonight. That is all that I ask. I apologise to Senator Harradine. I shall certainly take up his suggestion that we give more time for General Business early in the session. Considering the way that we shall have legislation left over this time, I think that we shall have a fair bit of legislation early next session.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Department of Special Minister of State

TALK.START.PARA: —With the indulgence of the Committee, I should like to make a statement on behalf of Senator Ryan concerning a wrong answer that was given last night. During the debate on the appropriations for the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism--
—Just as well we asked the question.

—If she were wrong as often as Senator Durack is, we would be here all day. Senator Ryan informed the Senate on advice that the Government had not endorsed the decision for the Australian Institute of Sport to become a statutory authority. I wish to inform the Senate that the Government has agreed to the Australian Institute of Sport becoming a statutory authority. This was agreed to at a Cabinet meeting on 13 November and endorsed by Cabinet on 18 November. This information was conveyed to Mr Peter White, the honourable member for McPherson, in a letter dated 26 November from the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). For the information of honourable senators, I will table a copy of the letter to Mr White.
—How much has been spent on the policing at the South African Embassy since the picket started?
—We have not got these details here, but I will get the figures for the honourable senator.

—In relation to the same matter, could we also be told from what part of the Budget that money comes, and what other police services have been deprived of resources to enable that presence of up to three policemen at times to be maintained?
