It seems from looking at these figures that the run-down purely of technical and skilled people in the Navy as a result of the Government's decision basically to get rid of the Fleet Air Arm resulted in the disbanding, if you like, the removal of skills that cost about $65m in total to generate. This $65m worth of skills that were available to the Navy are no longer available to the defence forces, and in many instances I am told are no longer available to Australia because many of those skills do not have commercial application. In fact, one of the best test pilots now runs two delicatessens in Nowra. There is simply not the capacity in Australia to provide tasks for him so that the skills he acquired can be properly used.

I wondered whether the Minister had some general view, emerging out of the information provided in response to the Estimates questions, of whether my stab of about $65m is a reasonable estimate of the cost of the skills lost to the Navy as a result of the decision to run down naval personnel, largely as a result of the decision to wipe out the Fleet Air Arm.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot confirm or deny the figures that Senator Michael Baume has put forward here today. I make the point, though, that this rundown was achieved by natural wastage. People were not shoved out of the Navy. The decision having been made that we no longer needed a fleet air arm, I am not quite sure of the point. I hope that Senator Baume is not putting the view that we should not have made that decision on the ground that we would, therefore, no longer employ technicians that we no longer needed.
—It is simply one of the hidden costs of making that decision.

—I will get the details of those costs of air crew training and the other technical training for the honourable senator. I do not know that I would ever be able to get anywhere near an accurate costing of the effects on Nowra, Jervis Bay or wherever else these people were living and working; but I shall certainly see what I can do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of numbers, I refer to the Rapid Deployment Force in Lavarack Barracks in Townsville. Honourable senators would know that the role of that force is primarily to respond with some degree of immediacy to any kind of emergency. The information that we have been given in the past is that, should there be an emergency, a company group would be at the point of readiness and available in up to seven days. I remind honourable senators that a company group is, I suppose, somewhere between 120 and 140 persons-not exactly a formidable force for an aggressor, even one that is patient enough to wait for up to seven days. As regards availability, I also understand that a battalion, presumably a battalion group, would be available in up to 14 days. Would such a battalion be a depleted battalion-that is, a battalion minus a company, or with, perhaps companies minus platoons-or would it be a full battalion? At a guess, a battalion group could be somewhere between 600 and 900 or 1,000 people. I gather that in one month we could put a brigade group into the field.

SPEECH.PARA: These figures have been stated and written repeatedly. They seem to have some element of absurdity about them. If we are to have a rapid deployment force, the very nature of it is that it must be able to respond with readiness. It is very hard to reconcile a permanent army of about 30,000-odd people capable of putting only about 120 persons in the field in up to seven days. Perhaps, over the course of the lunch break and the period until we resume consideration of these estimates, the Minister will be able to throw light upon where the defects are in what I have said, and whether there is any more instant solution. I am aware of the existence of Special Air Service units. But they are specifically not designed to be committed fighting troops; they have special roles. As I understand it, the Rapid Deployment Force is the fighting force, and I believe that the people of Australia could hardly reconcile that kind of program with any sense of urgency or immediacy.
Sitting suspended from 12.44 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION: INDUSTRIAL ACTION BY TRADE UNIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to comments by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, on the AM program this morning when he said that company superannuation schemes would be untouched by the deal done to resolve the crisis brought about by industrial action by the Federated Storemen and Packers Union. Is it a fact that the settlement forced on employers at last night's talks with the Minister and the unions means that companies will be required to continue contributions to their own superannuation schemes and make additional contributions to union or other industry schemes? In other words, will last night's agreement require double superannuation payments by employers in respect of the same employees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that Mr Olsen must have Senator Messner's assistance in preparing those shonky accounts that he is presenting to the South Australian electorate. I did not hear the comments by Mr Willis this morning but I do have a note which appears to be a statement put out by Mr Willis after last night's meeting-it is dated yesterday-in which it is said:

ANSWER.PARA: The parties-
that is, the various unions concerned-

agree to the establishment of an industry superannuation scheme in the context of the Accord Mark II and subject to decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, including the decision in the National Productivity Case.
The industry scheme to apply from 1 July 1986 and to apply to all employees including those in company schemes.
The ACTU to co-ordinate union negotiations on the industry scheme.
The FSPU to be involved in the industry scheme but with contributions for its members to be paid to LUCRF.
I am not sure what the acronym LUCRF stands for. The note continues:
The admission agreement for LUCRF to be in conformity with the industry scheme in all possible respects.
The ACTU to seek to ensure that all other unions join the common industry scheme.
That company schemes remain untouched by development of the industry scheme.
I think the last point covers the one substantial question which Senator Messner asked. The note continues:
Any agreement reached will be reported to the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware of recent claims by a marine scientist that sugar cane growers living near coastal areas could switch from growing sugar cane to aquaculture and prawn farming? Has the Government given consideration to this proposal? If so, has it proven to be a viable alternative? Can the Minister say to what extent this concept has been tried in Australian conditions?

—I thought I had a note on that question. If I do, I do not seem to be able to find it. I am afraid that I shall just have to ask the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, whether he can supply any information along the lines requested by Senator Elstob.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION: INDUSTRIAL ACTION BY TRADE UNIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of a report that Australia's four major transport companies have received a telex from the Transport Workers Union demanding assent to a superannuation deal by 13 December under threat of industrial action from that date? What action will the Government take to thwart such blatant industrial blackmail, which runs counter to its own position on the timing of the introduction of new superannuation arrangements?

—I was asked whether I was aware of a telex allegedly sent by the Transport Workers Union. The answer is no, I am not aware of it. I will refer the rest of the question to Mr Willis for comment and reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. In view of the tragic loss of life in the Egypt Air seizure at Malta in recent days, at least partially attributable to the use of combustible materials in the cabin construction of modern passenger aircraft, would the Minister care to comment on developments in the use of alternative and safer materials in the Australian context?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has had this matter of the use of non-combustible materials in aeroplane construction under consideration for quite some time. I think the announcement this morning on AM is very relevant to the airline crashes that have taken place in Australia and, in particular, to the incident to which Senator Childs referred. It is interesting to note that the industry itself is taking steps to examine ways and means by which the incidence of fires in aeroplanes, particularly those involved in hijacks or crashes, would be able to be contained by the use of better non-combustible materials. As I understand it, the Department of Aviation has had a senior airworthiness engineer overseas studying this matter. Most honourable senators will be aware that a number of tragedies take place as a result of aeroplanes catching fire during a disturbance or a crash landing. The major aircraft manufacturers are seeking to establish new processes for outfitting the aeroplanes and, in so doing, reduce the incidence of fire on those occasions when a crash occurs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government is already aware of the developments that are taking place. We have already proceeded with discussions with the main manufacturers of aircraft with a view to reaching the objective of providing a safer type of structure and outfittings in the airline industry. When these matters have progressed further the Australian Government obviously will be taking steps in the future to insist on the method of outfitting aeroplanes purchased in Australia by both the government airline and the private airline industry, the purpose being, of course, to make this new and growing industry a safer one from the passenger's point of view.

One personal observation, having heard the statement on AM this morning of one spokesperson that the cost factor would have to be taken into account in any reconstruction of the airline industry, is that this seems to be of secondary consideration to the saving of lives. I hope that, in due course, those involved in the production of aeroplanes will be taking every step possible to reduce the incidence of fire should any difficulty occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry whether he is aware of a report in the Hobart Mercury of 22 November 1985 in which the Minister for Primary Industry is quoted as saying that there will be no logging where National Estate values are taken into account in any logging plan. Was that Minister accurately reported? If not, will the Minister clarify that Minister's attitude to logging in sensitive National Estate areas? Is it a fact that that Minister would allow logging in National Estate or World Heritage areas, such as the Douglas-Apsley, the Lemon Thyme and Western Tiers, the Jackeys March-Quamby area, or the southern forests? If so, from which areas, during which period and under what conditions? I did give the Minister previous notice of this question.

—My attention has been drawn to newspapers in Tasmania and on the mainland carrying many articles speculating about woodchip export licences and likely Government decisions. It is a question of considerable importance because of its employment implications and the importance of the forestry industry to Tasmania. For that reason the Government will not be taking any decision on this matter lightly. The Government currently has the question of licence renewals before it and does not expect any decision to be announced before the middle of December. Indeed, it is unlikely that the question will be formally considered by Cabinet much before then. Therefore, Mr Kerin advises me that he is not prepared to comment further to either substantiate or deny any proposals or predictions that have been made in the Hobart Mercury or any other newspaper.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the comment made yesterday by the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, that the recognition of sacred sites and all the hoo-ha that goes with it hindered progress. That comment is taken from this morning's Courier-Mail. Does a statement such as this indicate contempt for the culture of Australia's first inhabitants?

—I can only regret that any person in public life in Australia would make such an insulting comment about this country's first culture. It is regrettable but unfortunately it is not atypical of the Premier of Queensland that he should seek to be derogatory about a culture other than his own. In respect of sacred sites, our Government has introduced and passed Federal legislation which gives some protection to sacred sites if they are threatened by mining or some other development, although for the legislation to work properly it needs complementary State legislation. Unfortunately such legislation does not exist in Queensland. The only encouraging thing is that the view expressed by the Premier of Queensland would be shared by fewer and fewer Australians as Aboriginal Australians themselves become more successful in communicating to the rest of Australia the nature of their culture and the importance of sacred sites to it. It has been heartening to see the increasing recognition of and support for Aboriginal culture by, among others, the Christian churches. It is unfortunate that Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, who claims to be a Christian, has not adopted the more enlightened views that a lot of Christians in this country have. They have expressed their respect for Aboriginal culture and sites of significance within it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the answer which the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations gave in the House of Representatives yesterday when he said that the public sector would be included in the superannuation deal made by the Government with the Australian Council of Trade Unions which will give productivity gains through superannuation. I ask: Can the Minister give an indication of how the agreement on superannuation will be applied to the Commonwealth Public Service; and further, will these arrangements improve the benefits which already arise from a scheme which is acknowledged as being much more generous than private sector superannuation arrangements?

—In response to the final part of Senator Rae's question, while it is probably generally true to say what he did, I am certainly aware of private sector superannuation schemes which are more generous than the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, particularly when one takes into account the fact that lump sum payments are the norm and therefore people can get benefits from a private sector superannuation scheme and still conceivably qualify for the social security pension.
—But generally, though.

—Yes, generally; but it is important to note that there are more generous private sector schemes. I do not know of the answer that Mr Willis gave and therefore I can only speculate on precisely what he meant. But in that context it is possible that he was referring to Commonwealth employees currently outside the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. A high proportion-as I recall, the majority-of blue collar Commonwealth employees, for example, are not in the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and consideration has been given for some time by me and by Mr Willis to what might be done about this. So it is possible that he was referring to those principally blue collar employees of the Commonwealth not in the CSS, but I will ask him whether that is so and whether he has anything to add to it.

—Has the Minister for Education been made aware of continuing media reports in Tasmania that the Federal Government will not honour its commitment to nurse education in that State? In particular, has she been apprised of comments by the Premier to the effect that the State Government believed firmly that the Federal Government would meet capital establishment costs and provide $3,000 for each nurse in training to cover the costs of getting replacement staff in hospitals? Is there any basis for this asserted belief by the Premier?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no basis for the Premier or anyone else claiming that the Commonwealth at any stage undertook to provide capital funding for the transfer of nurse education to the colleges. Nor is there any basis for his claiming that the Commonwealth undertook to contribute to recurrent costs to the extent of $3,000 for each nurse each year. The fact of the matter is that the Commonwealth has offered a fair and reasonable contribution to the additional costs involved in the transfer of nurse education. Mr Gray is attempting to conceal from the people of Tasmania the fact that State governments are already funded to provide nurse education, through the States' health grants. As everybody in this place would know, the cost of training nurses has always been borne by the States. The States have had the revenue to do this through the--
—That is not true. Private hospitals still do it in Tasmania.

—Mr Deputy President, it is a bit difficult to answer questions when the interjections indicate absolutely no knowledge of the policy development that has gone on for the past two years. The fact of the matter is that the funds now being made available by the Commonwealth to assist in the transfer are in addition to the funds already given to the States for nurse education. There has been no offsetting of the States' health grants; there has been no attempt to deduct from those grants the cost of contributing to the college-based training.

ANSWER.PARA: So the States have their health grants intact, which up to this year have always covered the cost of nurse training, and as well as that they have additional funding. A considerable additional amount is available to them. For example, they have $1,500 per student-that is in 1983 prices, it is now considerably more than that; the cost of the tertiary education assistance scheme for those college-based nurse trainees who are eligible for TEAS is being borne by the Commonwealth; and we have already contributed over $3m for the retraining of nurses in the community who might like to be retrained to come back into the nursing work force. Just two weeks ago Dr Blewett and I announced a new package of assistance to the States to assist them in nurse training which consisted of another $4m for the retraining of nurses and $2.3m for curriculum development to assist those colleges that are now introducing nurse undergraduate courses, and an extra $1m for extra TEAS payments to any additional trainees that the States might like to support in colleges. All of this funding is in addition to the normal funds given to the States for nurse education. So the Commonwealth Government is making a net contribution to nurse education and the States have lost nothing. In fact, they have made a net gain because of the additional Commonwealth funding. The number of students that the Commonwealth is prepared to support next year in the Launceston College of Advanced Education is 50. Over the next period- that is, until 1990-we expect that States will phase in the development of the new policy so that no States will be faced with huge burdens at the outset. By 1993 when the transfer should be completed, if the States co-operate with our timetable, the Commonwealth will then take over the full cost of training nurses in tertiary institutions, although at that time it may be necessary to make some adjustment to the States' grants.

I state in conclusion-I realise I have been somewhat repetitious, but the point seems very hard to get through to Premier Gray-that the States have made a net gain. They will get several million dollars more for the new form of training of nurses than they got under the old system and they are retaining the funds that they were getting for the hospital-based system. It is obviously a fair and reasonable contribution by the Commonwealth, one which has been hailed by nurses throughout Australia as the most progressive policy for nurses ever implemented in Australia and one which has the entire support of the nursing profession. It also has the support of most State governments but unfortunately Tasmania, as usual, has decided to go out on a limb.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Why is the Government deceiving the Australian taxpayer by pretending to reduce personal income tax while the lack of bracket indexation ensures an ever increasing tax burden? Further, is the leadership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions aware of this deception and therefore a party to these efforts to trick taxpayers into lower real wages?

—Naturally I do not accept the unsupported assertion that the Government is deceiving taxpayers. The Government has published the rate scales which will be applied for the next two years, provided that the taxation package proposed by the Government goes through the Parliament. It is ironic, to say the least, that Senator Sheil should be raising the question of fiscal drag-that is, the higher proportion of income which is paid in taxation if real incomes remain constant but money incomes rise and a progressive rate scale remains unchanged. I recall that when the Fraser Government was elected in 1975 it was elected on a firm promise of full annual tax indexation. It did it for one year and in the succeeding year it applied only 50 per cent indexation and then the year after, with another election behind it, it abandoned indexation altogether. Therefore, what Mr Fraser used to call `taxation by stealth' was then practised by the Fraser-Howard Government for the succeeding five years without, so far as I can recall, any word of protest from Senator Sheil.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Resources and Energy. Recently a conference of State and Federal water, agriculture and environment Ministers met in Adelaide to consider the Murray-Darling basin. Can the Minister elaborate on the outcome of that meeting and the recommendations emerging from it? In particular, what are the prospects for the South Australian water supply and are there any changes for South Australia in the pipeline, so to speak?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have a note on the outcome of those discussions. I am advised that because of the very heavy dependence of South Australia on the River Murray for much of its water supply, particularly during poor seasons in South Australia itself and therefore poor storage in the local catchments, South Australia has a greater interest than most States in taking measures to arrest the declining quality of the water. The only effective strategy for achieving that objective is one which takes the kind of integrated, basin-wide perspective as that which was initiated at that historic meeting of the Murray-Darling basin management Ministers in Adelaide earlier this month. The meeting agreed to establish a ministerial council, consisting of senior Ministers of the four governments, to address the problems of water quality. I interpolate that it is a pity that the Queensland Government is not involved as well, since a substantial part of the Murray-Darling catchment area is in Queensland. The council will also address the problems of land management, soil conservation and environmental degradation over the system as a whole. The Commonwealth will provide $1m in 1986-87 for water related research in the basin, including the establishment of a program of research at the Peter Till laboratory in Albury and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation irrigation research centre at Griffith.

ANSWER.PARA: On other matters concerning South Australia's-and particularly Adelaide's-water supplies, the fact is that for some years, or in every Budget since this Government has been in office, the Commonwealth Government has provided significant financial assistance to the water filtration plants which the South Australian State Government is installing and which were mentioned by Mr Bannon in his policy speech for the present election. He said that the vigorous program was being continued to improve the quality of South Australia's water supply. The Morgan filtration plant which will provide water to the Iron Triangle cities of Whyalla, Port Augusta and Port Pirie will be commissioned ahead of schedule in July 1986. He also said that Adelaide's largest water filtration plant was now being constructed at Happy Valley which, by the time it was completed, would have the capacity to serve 40 per cent of Adelaide's population, by which time the vast majority of people in Adelaide would be receiving filtered water. This is an excellent example of a co-operative program between the State and Commonwealth Labor governments which has been working very well and making rapid progress towards providing the city of Adelaide and other towns in rural parts of South Australia which are connected to that water supply with the sort of water quality that is taken for granted in most other parts of Australia and to which the people of South Australia are entitled.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. As the Prime Minister gave a grant of $3,000 to assist the Bulletin flag competition, which involved a design for a new Australian flag and which ended up as such a debacle, and in view of the fact that the Prime Minister assured members of the other place yesterday that the Government had no intention of changing the flag at the moment, will the Government give a similar grant of $3,000 to the Australian Flag Association to encourage patriotism through education of the appropriateness of the Australian flag?
—I have not had the benefit of the Prime Minister's views on that matter, but I would strongly suspect that the answer would be no.
—It is in Hansard.

—Senator Walters asked me whether the Government would give $3,000 to some other collection of people and I am telling her that I suspect that the answer is no. I have not discussed this matter with the Prime Minister, but I still suspect that the answer is no. I will discuss it with the Prime Minister and then I will give Senator Walters a conclusive answer. In the meantime, if I might offer an opinion, it seems to me that the two situations that Senator Walters has described are quite different. Part of the competition to which she has referred involves the consideration of what is the appropriate flag, whether it be a new one or the present one.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and it refers to the current interest, both in Australia and overseas, in the question of privatisation of public assets. I refer in particular to the Thatcher Government's privatisation program. Are there any lessons for Australia in this program and are there any similarities between the Thatcher Government's program and the privatisation proposals of the South Australian Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are certainly lessons to be learned from the British experience. The principal lesson to be learned is that privatisation is a device used by Tory governments to fund current expenditure by flogging off public assets so that they can promise tax cuts immediately before an election. For example, the issue before last of the Guardian Weekly referred to the Thatcher Government's recently announced plans to sell off the British Gas Corporation and the British Airports Authority, both statutory monopolies, and the statutory monopoly will be preserved after the so-called privatisation. The Guardian Weekly made this observation:

ANSWER.PARA: The real reason for the sale of BGC and BAA is not even mentioned in the Queen's Speech. It is to raise cash for tax cuts in the run-up to the next election. British Gas alone (which made a cool billion profit last year) could command a price of anything up to #8 billion. If sold in three tranches this could add approaching #3 billion a year to the #2 billion plus privatisations already in the pipeline, and provide 3p in the pound of income tax reductions.
That is an across the board reduction in the rate of scale of 3 per cent. The Guardian Weekly asked rhetorically:
But who could seriously support income tax cuts financed by selling off the nation's capital assets?

Well, the answer apparently is that the Thatcher Government could support it and the Olsen Opposition supports it and plans to do precisely the same thing in South Australia in the highly unlikely event of its being elected on Saturday week.

Other similarities between the practices of the Thatcher Government and the proposals of the Olsen Opposition are that either, or sometimes both, of two conditions are applied. Firstly, the Government retains a majority equity in the organisation supposedly being privatised. For example, in British Oil the Thatcher Government retained a 51 per cent public equity, which happens to be precisely the same figure as the Olsen opposition proposes to retain in the South Australian Oil and Gas Corporation-that is, the majority of the ownership would remain in public hands. Similar arrangements apply in Great Briain to British Aerospace, British Telcom, British Petroleum, and Cable and Wireless. Secondly, in other public enterprises too numerous to mention a golden share provision applies. Irrespective of the level of equity, the public shareholder-that is, the Government-retains voting control of the companies allegedly privatised.

Another feature of the so-called privatisation in the United Kingdom is that in some instances it has in fact led to an increase in regulation. Given that the objective of the policy is to cash out capital assets-to fund current consumption by flogging off assets-it is not surprising that the regulation is maintained. The regulation frequently confers monopoly powers on the corporations which are allegedly being privatised and, because of those monopoly powers, the capacity to charge monopoly prices. So as well as selling off the physical assets which are owned by some of these corporations, the Thatcher Government is capitalising the anticipated economic rent which flows from the statutory monopolies that the corporations, having had parts of their equity sold off, possess.

There are lessons to be learned from the British experience-lessons which appear to be absorbed very effectively right now by the South Australian electorate-and there are also similarities. In both cases the underlying objective has been identical; that is, to deceive the people by funding tax cuts through flogging off physical assets owned by the public and capitalising anticipated economic rent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to the brochure recently issued to all householders by the Department of Communications, of which I have given a copy to the Minister, which gives details of the changeover from very high frequency to ultra high frequency for television broadcasting from 5 January 1986. Is it a fact that most television sets in Australia will not be able to receive Special Broadcasting Service telecasts unless they are so converted? Does this conversion include an additional UHF antenna, an outdoor feeder cable, and the cost of installation, being a total of approximately $130, together with a down converter costing approximately $120 for older sets? Have householders been advised to employ a competent technically qualified and experienced person to install them? Is the Government satisfied that there will be considerable loss of audience by SBS and a deprivation of services, particularly for our migrant community, if this plan goes ahead? Has any arrangement been made to compensate persons of small means, who will suffer the loss of these services, for these changes forced upon them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first question as to whether most television sets will not be able to receive SBS telecasts, the answer is no. The best advice is that the great majority of Australian sets are capable of tuning to the UHF band. It is impossible to answer whether there will be costs to any particular household, because it may or may not be necessary to incur expenditure of the type to which Senator Missen referred. I suggest that Senator Missen might one day have a look at SBS in Canberra, or ask any Canberra resident, and he might then discover that many receive a satisfactory SBS UHF signal without resort to any such expense.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the audience SBS has, that is a matter of pure speculation. Senator Missen's final question was whether any arrangement would be made to compensate persons to avoid the loss of the service. That is a preposterous suggestion, for this reason: The former Government, of which Senator Missen, if I remember correctly, was a member, commenced the SBS as an ultra high frequency service. To assist in the introduction of the UHF service it was decided by the former Government to permit the SBS also to broadcast simultaneously on very high frequency Channel O in Melbourne and Sydney for a limited time. The limited time was extended by this Government to assist the changeover in Melbourne and Sydney. Therefore, the idea of compensation in those sorts of circumstances is preposterous and would constitute a grotesque imposition on the rest of the taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Acting Minister for Resources and Energy. Given the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority's recent clearance of a testing project for the extraction of uranium by the leaching method at Meninygee near Onslow, I ask: What arrangements have been made for the disposal of the six drums of uranium oxide already mined at Meninygee? Has any of the uranium mined at Meninygee been exported and, if so, to what countries? Is it not against Australian Labor Party policy to encourage uranium exploration while there is a prohibition on new uranium contracts? In view of the fact that the companies involved are French companies actively seeking French contacts, should not the Federal Government disallow this exploration, in view of the current moratorium on direct sales to France?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that no arrangements have been made for disposal of the uranium oxide in question, although the physical security of the drums has been examined and approved by the Australian Safeguards Office. None of the uranium at Meninygee has been exported, therefore the second part of the question does not arise. Senator Vallentine's third question referred to it being against Labor Party policy to encourage uranium exploration. She then went on to ask why the Federal Government had not disallowed this exploration. The short answer to that is that exploration within the States is under the control of the State governments and the Federal Government has no power to prevent exploration in or on State territory. Even if it did have such power, the question would still arise of what is exploration for uranium and what is exploration for some other mineral.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the honourable senator's reference to the company whose ultimate owner is Total Holdings (Aust.) Pty Ltd and which is substantially French-owned, all mining companies, whether French or not, are well aware of the Commonwealth Government's policy. Whether they choose to explore for any mineral or seek approval from State governments to do so is essentially a matter for their commercial judgment and for the policy decisions of the States.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TUGGERANONG RETAIL COMPLEX SITE AND BELCONNEN MALL

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. Will the deferred auction of the Tuggeranong retail complex site be open only to builders who guarantee that they will follow Government policy on the Builders Labourers Federation? Will tenderers for the Belconnen Mall have to give a similar undertaking in relation to the extra retail and office space that can be developed at that site? Will tenderers also have to agree to maintain occasional child care facilities in Belconnen Mall indefinitely now that the Department of Territories has realised that Mall tenants, and not the Government, subsidise those facilities?

—Three questions were asked of me by Senator Vigor. The answer to the first question is yes. As to the second question, tenders for the sale of Belconnen Mall were called prior to the announcement of the Government's industrial policy. Application of that policy with respect to the BLF to the sale of the Mall is currently under consideration. In respect of the third question asked of me regarding tenderers for the Mall and their responsibilities in respect of child care facilities and so on, tenderers have been asked to specify their intentions in relation to the long term provision of child care. Tenderers' proposals in this regard will be taken into account in assessing tenders. In other words, their intentions in regard to that responsibility and obligation will be considered by the Government and their applications accorded recognition depending on their response.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Commonwealth Banking Corporation developed an equal employment opportunity program or appointed an equal employment opportunity officer? Is there any requirement for the Bank to comply with equal employment opportunity provisions as they apply to the Australian Public Service?

—The answer to the last part of the question is no, for these reasons: The Public Service Reform Act of 1984 makes provision for departments to prepare an equal employment opportunity program. For the purposes of legislation, departments are defined to include statutory authorities which are staffed under the Public Service Act and headed by a person with the powers of a departmental secretary. Other authorities staffed under the Public Service Act are covered by the EEO program of the Department to which they are attached. The Commonwealth Banking Corporation is staffed under provisions of Part VIII of the Commonwealth Banks Act and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation service regulations. It is, therefore, not subject to the Public Service Act or the Public Service Reform Act of 1984 and, consequently, is not legally required to prepare an EEO program. However, I understand that, notwithstanding the absence of any legal requirement to do so, the Commonwealth Bank is in the process of implementing a program similar to those which are being applied in the Public Service generally.

—I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the view expressed by the Attorney-General yesterday that `it would be appropriate' to use the Bill of Rights legislation to change the electoral systems of Western Australia and Queensland. I also refer the Minister to the comment by Premier Burke of Western Australia that his Government had always maintained that the matter should be dealt with in Western Australia; in other words, by the State.
—What about the Legislative Council of Western Australia?

—I am telling honourable senators what Premier Burke thinks about the whole subject. The honourable senator should listen to what his Premier-in fact, his boss-said. I ask the Minister: Do the views expressed by the Attorney-General represent a decision of the Federal Government? Does the Minister agree that any changes to State electoral laws should be dealt with by the electors in the States and not by the Federal Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of the question really depends on the circumstances which prevail. I cite the Western Australian case, for example, as Senator Durack has mentioned it, and the unscrupulous actions of the Western Australian Liberal Party to which he belongs and which for years justified electoral malapportionment in Western Australia on the grounds that people who live in remote and sparsely populated portions of the State are entitled to have a larger number of parliamentarians per capita or a fewer number of electors per parliamentarian than those who live in the metropolitan area. Having used those grounds for decades as a rationale for the Western Australian malapportionment, the last Liberal Government in Western Australia put through a redistribution which changed the boundaries of the four statutory seats-Murchison-Eyre, Carnarvon, Pilbara and Kimberley.

ANSWER.PARA: It changed it in this way: The seat of Kimberley, which formerly had the second largest area of any of those four statutory seats, was enlarged to take in all the inland mining towns in the Pilbara, giving it a consequential enrolment greater than that of some seats in the metropolitan area of Perth and an area of about 20 per cent of the entire State, an area very much greater than the electorate of Carnarvon-also a statutory seat, that is, the boundaries being determined by statute-with three times as many electors as the electorate of Carnarvon and four times the area. Why were the boundaries changed to achieve that result?

TALK.START.PARA: —Who won the seat?

—The Liberals miscalculated. They are not only shonky; they are incompetent as well. The boundaries were changed in order to put into the seat of Kimberley, which was already firmly held by the Australian Labor Party, the inland Pilbara towns which had a long tradition of recording heavy Labor votes, leaving in the residual seat, in the residue of the old Pilbara electorate, the coastal towns which until that stage had had a record of voting for the Liberal Party. So the whole purpose of that shonky exercise, organised by Charlie Court and supported by Hassell and all the other shonks in the Western Australian Liberal Party, was to-
—Mr Deputy President-
—There is another shonk. There is a speculator in Poiseidon shares, an inside player!

—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I resent the expressions that have been used by the Minister. He is normally a temperate person, but he is using the word `shonks' of members of the Liberal Party. I find that offensive. I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to request the Minister to withdraw.
—Order! Normally, collective descriptions are not against the Standing Orders, but in this case Senator Walsh also referred to a particular individual as being shonky and he should withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr Deputy President.
—The collective is still available.

—Yes, collectively, `shonky' is a description that fits the Western Australian Liberal Party very well. The purpose of the change in boundaries was to save the seat of Pilbara for the Liberal Party. I thank Senator Durack for drawing my attention to the fact that the Liberals miscalculated and lost the Pilbara as well. But the exercise demonstrates the extremes to which corrupt State branches of the Liberal Party, and the National Party of Australia in the case of Queensland, are willing to go, and the degree to which they are willing to manipulate the electoral system, to retain power for themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Durack evidently takes the view that no matter what any State government does, no matter how corrupt any State government is and no matter how grotesque its electoral system, it is no business of any other part of Australia. I believe that is not a view which many people outside the Western Australian Liberal Party or the Queensland National Party would endorse.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am putting forward the views of Premier Burke.

—As far as I know Premier Burke has never endorsed the shonky arrangements engineered by the Western Australian Liberal Party when the boundaries of the four statutory seats were redetermined in 1982. Indeed, I think that Premier Burke is on record many times as being highly critical of that, as he, of course, should be. As for Mr Lionel Bowen's alleged comments, I did see some reference to this in the Press. I am not sure of the context in which those remarks were made and I will ask Mr Bowen for a response.

—I ask a supplementary question. When I asked the Minister whether he agreed with Premier Burke's view that these matters should be left to the State, he said that it would depend upon the circumstances. Can the Minister tell us what are the circumstances in which such a matter should be taken over by the Federal Parliament contrary to the wishes of the State?
—I have nothing to add to what I said before.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation seen the comments by the Liberal member for Bass, Mr Smith, criticising the present Federal Government for its administration of the two-airline policy, claiming that Launceston was being penalised? Is it not a fact that the Opposition when in government twice negotiated the two-airline agreement for lengthy periods, far longer than the Labor Opposition wished at each of those times, thereby preventing subsequent Labor governments from effectively reviewing the legislation? Further, does the Government have a response to the call by East-West Airlines for a three-airline agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite amazed at the statements that Mr Warwick Smith from Tasmania has made on the two-airline agreement as, indeed, one can be amazed at the statement made by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Ian Sinclair, on that agreement and their suggestions that it ought to be turned into a three-airline agreement. I am amazed at the hypocrisy of the Opposition parties as they thrash about trying to establish some of their policies. They are aware, or at least they should be aware, of the circumstances behind the two-airline agreement. One could argue that Mr Smith was either ignorant or deceitful in his approach and in his public comments on the two-airline agreement. It is a notorious fact that on the eve of two Federal elections at the end of the eight-year cycle on which the airline agreement is negotiated both the McMahon Government and the Fraser Government in their dying days renegotiated the agreement. The present agreement involves the Commonwealth Government in a legal contract with both Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia which cannot be broken, no matter whether it is the wish of this Government or any other government to do so, until its expiry date-1990.

ANSWER.PARA: As the public record shows in Hansard, when the two-airline agreement was being rammed through the Parliament in 1972 and later in 1981 Labor members violently opposed the legislation because it would hamstring a future government's attempts to renegotiate the two-airline agreement. It is rather hypocritical of Opposition spokesmen to attempt to say now that we are refusing to do anything about the two-airline agreement when it is not possible, even if legislation were to be passed in the Parliament, to break the agreement, which is a three-party agreement. It is all right for State Premiers and Opposition members to talk about breaking the agreement, but this Government's hands are tied. One can only come to the conclusion that a great deal of hypocrisy is being applied to this matter.

Attempts have been made to portray East-West Airlines, which is probably sponsoring the Opposition's approach to this matter and which knows full well that the two-airline agreement ties the hands of government, as a small independent operator or a small business operator somehow or other caught up in a struggle against the giants of the airline industry. That might have been the position of East-West in its early days, but it has now been taken over by a big operator. It is now a large corporation. That corporation knew what the circumstances were when it bought out East-West Airlines in 1983. Therefore, no matter what views this Government might have, the Minister for Aviation and this Government can do nothing about the two-airline agreement until 1990.
Let me inform the Senate that when the current Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir, Mr Hunt, was debating this matter in May 1981, he said:
I believe every minute of the 8-year period of agreement will be needed.

It is common knowledge that the Prime Minister at that time forced the Cabinet to agree to that proposition. When we consider the attitude that was taken by Sir Robert Menzies when the two-airline agreement was first put into effect way back in the 1960s, what is happening to the Liberal Party today in respect of such matters as the two-airline agreement and its economic policy makes Sir Robert Menzies look like a left wing liberal.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I draw his attention to media reports of the New South Wales Government's contribution of $115,000 to the First Fleet Re-enactment Committee's $11m project to recreate the entire Plymouth to Sydney First Fleet voyage. The launching of this project was made yesterday by the New South Wales Premier and followed the cancellation of Saturday's launch by the Prime Minister of the Australian Bicentennial Authority's tall ships project launch. I ask the Minister: In light of the obvious conflict between two similar projects, what is now the status of the tall ships project and is the Federal Government likely to fund either or both of those projects? Does this mean that the Federal Government is all at sea with the Australian Bicentennial Authority or is it that it has no wind left in its sails?

—As we are going in for wet jokes, I remind the honourable senator that there is no such thing as a free launch. Perhaps that is why the Prime Minister did not proceed with that function last week. The answer to the substance of the question is that, as I understand it, the tall ships project is still proceeding. The Australian Bicentennial Authority is now under new chairmanship and it will be making announcements about its reviewed set of programs shortly. I imagine that the tall ships project will proceed. If I might volunteer a personal view, it may be possible to engineer some battle between the two fleets, and that might not be a bad thing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the report in the Canberra Times of last Friday headed: `No mass job losses in restaurants: CES'? I ask the Minister whether he is aware that the article in part reads:

QUESTION.PARA: Nationwide, the total number of hotel and restaurant vacancies notified to the CES during October 1985 was higher than at any time since October 1984, and represented a 25.9 per cent increase over the year.
Do not the Commonwealth Employment Service statistics finally put the lie to the Opposition's claims of 30,000 jobs lost throughout Australia because of the business lunch tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another issue which draws attention to the propensity of the Opposition to believe whatever it chooses to believe regardless of the objective realities.
—Senator Messner, particularly.

—Yes, Senator Messner in particular. The Opposition, under the tutelage of its temporary leader, is pursuing a policy of deregulation of the labour market and the abandonment of centralised wage fixing in the expectation that that will lead to a slower rate of wages growth, based on the assumption that this is a completely competitive economy with completely competitive markets for labour, services and commodities. It is not, but the Opposition continues to believe that it is. Likewise, the Opposition apparently continues to believe that there will be massive losses in the catering industry because of the termination of the free lunch. The story to which Senator Cook referred as well as the facts that he mentioned show that in all States other than Victoria or Tasmania there were increases in the number of vacancies in the catering industry following the termination of the free lunch. I certainly would not argue with or fall for the logical fallacy that this increase in the number of vacancies was necessarily caused by the termination of the free lunch, but I think it does demonstrate to any person with some sort of nodding acquaintance with reality that there was little if any correlation between the level of employment in the industry and the free lunch.

ANSWER.PARA: I also noted that the demonstration outside Parliament House yesterday was not particularly well attended, which I suppose is testimony to two things: Firstly, that the people who are genuinely seeking employment in the catering industry are around at the CES offices, if they have not already got a job, getting the names of all those employers who want workers and who cannot get them. That is where the genuine workers in the catering industry could be expected to be. Secondly, whoever it was who organised the demonstration out there-I suppose this is an alternative point rather than a second one-did not have sufficient funds to rent a big enough crowd to make an impressive demonstration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from Mr Duffy, the Minister for Communications, pursuant to questions raised in the Senate on 14 November by Senator Colston regarding Australian Broadcasting Corporation coverage of race meetings in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Communications
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Senator M. A. Colston
Senator for Queensland
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

In response to your inquiries made during the Senate Adjournment Debate on 14 November 1985, I have raised with the ABC all the points with which you have taken issue. Below I have addressed each matter in turn, the answers being provided for me by the ABC.

Point one-You have pointed out that you do not believe the reasons given to me by the ABC in response to an earlier Parliamentary Question asked by you regarding the termination of the ABC's race commentator, Mr Larry Pratt's radio contract.

The ABC has assured me that the ending of race broadcasts in Brisbane and the termination of Mr Pratt's services were made as a means of adapting to current funding restrictions and also as a means of avoiding duplication of programs. The measures taken were those which had proved to be available to the ABC. This was because 4BC was also providing a racing service to Metropolitan Brisbane, therefore the decision taken by the ABC would not deprive this locality's race listeners of their only access to race broadcasts. As you are already aware in Brisbane the ABC now provides a mix of race results and other sporting features.

Point two-You have queried the accuracy of the response to your question concerning the source of the ABC's regional racing broadcasts ie. that they are relayed from Brisbane commercial radio station 4BC's racing program and therefore do not constitute the ABC's own racing program.

The ABC's regional racing program includes the use of Brisbane race calls made by a ``course commentator''. An agreement was reached between ABC and TAB management giving the ABC access to the course commentator for the race calls. This caller is also used by 4BC for that stations race broadcasts. However, at no time is the ABC regional race program that of 4BC's as the line from the race course goes only to the switchroom of 4BC; here the line is ``split'' i.e. the broadcast goes into the ABC studios at Toowong on one line whilst it goes to the 4BC studio on another. This means that there is no input into the ABC relay of any of 4Bc's studio programming. 4BC's programming occurs in the 4BC studio and utilizes the race call as part of its own program as does the ABC. The race call used by the ABC is in fact technically redirected to the ABC's studios before it reaches 4BC's studios. The only relationship between 4BC and the ABC is based on the fact that they use the services of the same Brisbane on-course race commentator. Also the ABC does not pay either the course commentator of 4BC for access to the Brisbane race calls.

Point three-You disagree with the ABC's response to your query about whether or not there is accidental inclusion of commercials in the ABC relay. You suggest that due to delays and the ABC ``channelling in on the 4BC program'' it is impossible not to have commercials come over the ABC relay.

Radio commericals are usually put to air within the program at the studio point of the broadcast either by the studio announcer or a technical booth operator linked to the studio. As pointed out above, the ABC does not channel in on the 4BC program, the split in the line for the ABC occurring before 4BC studio programming inserts are made. However what has occurred is that the ABC's Queensland Branch received some complaints from regional listeners because the ABC was crossing over to the race caller just before the start of the race and listeners felt they were missing the pre-race betting fuctuations and the pre-race build-up commentary. The ABC then decided to include this material where possible by crossing to the course earlier. This involved a foreseen but acceptable risk as to what the race caller might say if he had to fill in time. In the event there have been isolated instances of some commercial-related comments alluded to e.g. references to an airline-sponsored tour, going to air on ABC regional stations. However, no radio commercials as such have been broadcast on the ABC service.
In this respect I refer to Sections 31 (1), 31 (2) and sub-section (2) (c) of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 which states that:
31 (1) The Corporation shall not broadcast or televise advertisements.
(2) Sub-section (1) does not prevent the Corporation, if the Board thinks fit, from broadcasting or televising-
(c) a program supplied by any organisation or person other than a program that is, in the opinion of the Board, being used as an advertisement.

The evidence seems to support the conclusion that whilst some commentary matters emanating from the race commentator could perhaps be construed as being of a commercial nature such matter does not constitute a program that is being used as an advertisement. Therefore I am satisfied that the ABC is not breaking any requirements under its Act in relation to commercial advertising.
Point four-You have pointed out that there are some geographical areas where neither the ABC regional race program nor the 4BC metropolitan race program can be picked up.

This is certainly true in the case of the Sunshine Coast. Under the new arrangements, this area does not receive ABC regional race broadcasts, however this state of affairs will be remedied when a new ABC radio station is opened as part of the Second Regional Radio Network.
I am including below, for your, further information, a resume of what is broadcast on ABC regional stations for racing enthusiasts.
10.02-10.14 a.m.-Two way Turf Talk with Geoff Mahoney and Greg Miles discussing Sydney and Melbourne Racing.
10.14-10.20 a.m.-Geoff Mahoney with either Paul Colan or Michael Wrona discussing the Brisbane meeting.
12.00-6.00 p.m.-ABC Saturday Sport.
Late previews of Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane racing.
Descriptions of Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne racing and results from the Gold Coast and any other major race on which the TAB may be operating.
As applicable, win, place, quinella, doubles, trebles, trifectas and six pick prices are broadcast as soon as they are available.
Approximates for doubles, trebles and extra doubles are also given when available.
After the last race, a full race roundup is presented of meetings at Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne and the Gold Coast.

I trust that the information I have now been able to give you satisfies the interest you have taken in this matter. But if there are further matters about which you may wish to seek clarification please do no hesitate to contact me again.
Yours sincerely,
MICHAEL DUFFY

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 28A, I lay on the table a warrant withdrawing, at his request, Senator Tate from the panel of Temporary Chairmen of Committees and appointing Senator Giles to the panel in his place.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Messner proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The trade union domination of the Government, particularly on the superannuation issue, to the detriment of the Australian community.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point at issue today could not have been put before the Senate at a more important time, as it was only today that we saw the Government capitulate in the face of union pressure on the question of the demands of the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia for superannuation benefits on top of superannuation benefits which have already been provided by employers through normal superannuation schemes. This is a clear example of the way in which unions are exercising their power most successfully over the Hawke Labor Government. It is not only that it is occurring in that particular industry, the paint industry, which of course has devastating effects on the car industry. In addition, the way that this will impact upon South Australia is well known to many of us. The point is that as a result of this action we have seen clear evidence of the agreement of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, to an arrangement which in effect agrees to all of the union demands and makes sure that in future there will be a spread of further double superannuation benefits right across the industrial landscape of Australia. We have only to look back about 18 months to find out where the roots of this matter really lie. Mr Willis, in the House of Representatives on 31 May 1984, when talking generally about the way in which superannuation schemes would be extended across the community, said:

SPEECH.PARA: One way in which we can do that-
that is increase superannuation-

is by tying up the superannuation scheme, including an industrial relations agreement which is the key basis on which the Government has supported the extension of superannuation in the building industry. It also has to be genuine superannuation and there must be an orderly extension of superannuation schemes after that. The ACTU has given us that assurance.
He then quoted from a telex which he had received from Mr Kelty, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which reads as follows:
. . . the ACTU reaffirms its commitment given to you verbally that
1. the proposed building industry superannuation scheme will not form the basis for flow-on of such schemes to other areas, and
2. the further development of occupational superannuation will proceed in a gradual and orderly manner.

That was a firm and solemn commitment given by the ACTU to Mr Willis, the relevant Minister, some 18 months ago. But what has happened since? We have since seen the development of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia scheme, the development of schemes for the Transport Workers Union of Australia, for the Australian Timber Workers Union and other unions. In no way can they be referred to as being orderly developments; in fact they are the reverse. The classic example of that comes forward as a result of what happened yesterday, when we saw the Government forced on to the defensive, cowering before the demands of the trade unions. There has been a capitulation in the paint industry to the Storemen and Packers Union and a granting of an industry-wide, union based compulsory superannuation over and above the superannuation that is provided by the industry itself. In other words the pressure that is now upon the industry and, in particular, the Government in this regard has proven impossible to stop.

Perhaps the worst aspect of the whole thing is that there is obviously no control over this development, notwithstanding what Mr Kelty said at some earlier stage and notwithstanding what the ACTU has said to the Government as to how this would be controlled. The fact is that the unions are running wild irrespective of their intentions in previous days as to how this development may occur. In fact, we now see a rash of industrial action breaking out all over the country which will obviously impact on places where industries find it very difficult to cope with such things.

The present kinds of superannuation schemes are not about retirement benefits for employees but about naked union power. One does not have to be too clever to work out how it is that this development can lead only to compulsory unionism. We have already seen it in the building industry, where it is impossible to work on sites in Brisbane-Senator Parer will be developing that argument later-and in other places unless one is a member of the building industry superannuation scheme and unless one is by natural extension a member of a trade union. It is therefore through this means that the union movement will be extending coverage to all workers in the community by gradual extension of superannuation, wider and wider across the industrial landscape.

At the centre of all these changes we have seen none other than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during his period as President of the ACTU from 1969 to 1980, at a time when he presided over the most disastrous unemployment figures, the most disastrous inflation and the most disastrous wage increases in Australia's history, that created such problems for the Australian economy that we are still learning to live with. We saw him as a business manager fail with ACTU-Solo, fail with the Bourkes stores and indeed create all kinds of other problems for the community. We have now observed this bull in the china shop approach by allowing superannuation increases and developments to go uncontrolled in such a way that there will be no ultimate benefit for the nation and which can certainly be described only as deferred wage increases. There is no attempt by this Government to develop guidelines upon which proper retirement schemes can be developed, in such a way that we can take the load off the Department of Social Security, and in such a way that we can improve the lot of individual Australians. That is where our basic argument on this issue stands, but the Government has merely capitulated in the face of union pressure on this matter. Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, is not only incompetent and vacillating but also obviously weak. Apart from that, he is also a liar. He lied in South Australia yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I believe the honourable senator has been guilty of the most gross abuse of decorum of this place in using very unparliamentary language concerning the Prime Minister. I ask that it be withdrawn.
—Senator Messner, you cannot refer to a member of the other House in that way. Will you please withdraw?

—I withdraw, but I say that the Prime Minister is guilty of untruths. For instance, yesterday in South Australia he said that the policies of the Leader of the Opposition in that State, John Olsen, to reduce the size of government were illegal. He referred to the fact that the proposed Liberal government in South Australia would seek to sell off South Australian Housing Trust homes to those who need them. Olsen said no such thing. In fact the sale of homes under the Liberal Party's housing policy in South Australia will be done by renegotiation of the Commonwealth-State housing agreement. In no way can that be called an illegal act under that agreement. As the Prime Minister continues to reassert that untruth, I can refer to it only in the way that I did earlier. Obviously, that renegotiation of the housing agreement with the Commonwealth will be very important for South Australians. It will give South Australians an opportunity to own their own homes rather than to pay rent forever. Certainly the intention of the Liberal Party in South Australia is to ensure that that opportunity is extended.

SPEECH.PARA: It will also produce the benefit of funds received from those people who finance their homes in that way being put into building more rental housing. It is only under the present Labor Government in South Australia that we have seen an abnormal rate of growth, a record rate of growth, in the rental housing list. We are finding that more and more people in South Australia cannot get rental homes through the South Australian Housing Trust. Mr Olsen has a worthwhile solution to that problem, but all the Prime Minister can say in a desperate attempt to defend his position is that the solution is in some way illegal. That is untrue. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, knows that it is untrue. The Prime Minister knows that it is untrue. Fortunately, the people of South Australia know that this is a worthwhile benefit. They will certainly explain that to the Hawke Labor Government when they vote on 7 December.
We have heard much razzamatazz from the Bannon Labor Government in South Australia about things such as the Grand Prix and how the State is up and running. Yet the very project he is looking at--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. The Senate has before it a matter of public importance in terms which were submitted to the Deputy President this morning. I believe that the honourable senator is digressing, in total irrelevancy to the topic of superannuation and the alleged trade union domination of the Government.
—Senator Messner, you were rather getting away from the terms of the matter of public importance. Will you return to it, please?

—I will certainly obey your wishes, Madam Acting Deputy President. With the union domination that exists in South Australia, how is it that the Premier, Mr Bannon, can claim that he can deliver the goods. Let us consider the submarine contract, for instance. He has claimed that he is the only person who can deliver the submarine contract to South Australia, yet the other day the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, in the House of Representatives, acting under the union pressure, said that it has to be spread all over Australia. The Premier of South Australia claims that he is the only person who can deliver it. Of course that is not true.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of all, Mr Bannon, under pressure from the trade union movement, is claiming full support for the economic and tax policies of the Treasurer, Mr Keating. We know that Mr Keating's words drip from his mouth and that they are nothing more than really crude vulgarities, but the point is that Keating is the man whom Bannon supports. Keating is the man who goes overseas to save the Australian dollar and costs us all another $4 billion as the dollar falls through the floor. While it is true that Premier Bannon would not speak in the way that Keating does, the point has to be made that he supports Keating's policies. Keating supports high interest rates; so does Bannon. Keating wants a capital gains tax; so does Bannon. Who wants a fringe benefits tax? Keating does and, of course, that has to be supported by Bannon. Keating wants to destroy the hospitality industry in South Australia, so does Senator Walsh, and so does Mr Bannon.

Fairness and incentive in the way in which the tax system has operated will be destroyed by the Hawke Labor Government, and that has the full support of the Bannon Labor Government in South Australia, under union pressure emanating from Trades Hall. We know that all honourable senators on the Government side are subject to Trades Hall for their preselection. We know that they all have to give commitments to the unions in order to keep their places in the Senate. We ought to have a declaration of public interest to ensure that those guys tell us the truth about the commitments they give to people. That sort of thing applies not only at the Federal level but of course also at the State level.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I find it highly offensive that the honourable senator has made an imputation against members on this side of the chamber, in particular in implying that I am beholden to any outside body in regard to my obtaining a position in this chamber. I ask that that be withdrawn.
—Senator Messner, insofar as there was any imputation against Senator Tate, I suggest that you withdraw it.

—I am only too pleased to withdraw it. Senator Walsh apparently will not take part in this debate. I suppose that is reasonable because he gets his stories wrong all the time, and he has particularly done so with regard to the state of play with Mr Olsen in South Australia, which he repeated here today. Of course, one of the points about Senator Walsh is that he is a great non-succeeder as a Finance Minister, as we have seen. He cannot even get his expenditure cuts through the Cabinet, as was reported recently. The cuts to veterans' entitlements that he announced last May have not occurred. He cannot get any child care cuts through the Cabinet, and he has now faced an ignominious defeat on the issue of public authorities and trying to introduce rules and guidelines for them. I support that and so does my Party-that we ought to be able to control statutory authorities in a proper way. What is the argument put in the other direction? Apparently the Cabinet has knocked over Senator Walsh on that issue because it says that it does not want the Opposition to make any capital out of privatisation on the ground that statutory authorities are inefficient. If that is the case, Senator Walsh should talk to Mick Young a little more deeply about that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the issue of the union domination of the Government in South Australia, I refer to Mr Bannon's support of Mr Keating's interest rate policy. We know what that means. We know that in South Australia interest rates are causing enormous problems with mortgages for people in the north-eastern and the south-western suburbs. People are struggling to meet their repayments under the Keating interest rate policy. But not only those people are affected. Obviously, Government senators in this place support that high interest rate policy. Mr Bannon certainly supports it. In fact on the National the other night, in response to a question from an interviewer about the interest rate policy, he said that he accepted that the pressure on interest rates will continue and that many more people will be in trouble. Apparently, his advice at that time was that interest rates will go down. Of course, we know where his advice came from. It was from Mr Keating, who has been promising that all through 1985. Mr Bannon continues to support Mr Keating's economic policies, which are proving so disastrous, in particular for South Australians.

His policy of high interest rates is deliberate; it is important in supporting the price of the dollar before it collapses through the floor. We know that the cause of the falling dollar is the lack of competitiveness in this country, brought about by trade union pressures, which have not been assisted by today's announcement of the Government's cave-in to the paint industry. That is just part and parcel of the very real difficulties that Australians will face in the year ahead through these continuing high interest rate policies which are supported by the State Government of South Australia.

I conclude by saying that, central to the whole economic policy of the Keating plan, the maintenance of a high interest rate structure in this country is merely as a result of the pressure from the trade union movement. The unions, through their domination of the Government, control its every word and deed, and that lies at the very core of our economic policies and difficulties. It is the Government's desertion of its responsibilities and its obligations to the Australian people in its failure to assert its political authority over the growing power and pressure of the trade union movement that brings in its wake enormous problems, anguish and despair to so many Australians. We have only to consider the benefits of such policies as lead to the operation of such firms as the Mudginberri abattoir to observe what can happen when there is a better approach to industrial relations, and how benefits can flow to workers more freely as a result of those kinds of policies. But no, this Government is pushed and absolutely cowed by the trade unions, which are going in exactly the opposite direction.

However, the people of Australia can fight back. Next Saturday week, in South Australia, people can vote out the Bannon Labor Government and show Australians the lead. The opportunity lies not only in the streets of Adelaide but in the suburbs of the north-eastern and south-western parts of Adelaide, in Modbury, in Tea Tree Gully, in Warradale, in Brighton, in Whyalla, and in the timber towns of the south-east, and particularly Mount Gambier, which has been so ill-treated by this Government's policy in regard to road transport-something we have campaigned against strongly in this Senate. That will mean that Mount Gambier stays a strong Liberal seat in the future. That is the message from all Australians which, on 7 December, we can get through to the Hawke Labor Government, so that it understands that its policies are hurting Australians and are damaging the long term propsects of our economy-and that results directly from its domination by the trade union movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —One always knows when the Liberals are not doing well in the polls; they bring on a union bashing matter of public importance. Again we have it here today. What an unimpressive performance Senator Messner has put in today. I do not think that it is up to his normal reasonable standard. But it is true to say that Liberals hate trade unions. I have never met a Liberal who does not hate trade unions. If there is one thing that unites all the disparate factions of the Liberal Party of Australia, it is their hatred of trade unions. If they did not have trade unions to hate, they would have to invent them.
